Name: Dish
Description: Shallow red pottery dish, excavated at the key early settlement near Kom el-Ahmar (the Hierakonpolis of later texts) in southern Upper Egypt. The grave goods date the burial to the second half of the fourth millennium, when the culture of Upper Egypt was expanding northwards over Lower Egypt. From this and other burial goods in the rich tomb, the burial can be dated to the end of the Naqada II Period, on the eve of the unification of Upper and Lower Egypt in the final stage of state formation. During this period Kom el-Ahmar was a major centre of the emerging Egyptian kingship.
